items.headline: US Stocks Stage Late-Day Rally on Tariff Reversal, Major Indices Close Higher for the Week
items.summary: U.S. equity markets closed Friday, February 20, 2026, with gains across major indices, staging a significant reversal from earlier losses. This turnaround was largely propelled by a Supreme Court ruling that struck down sweeping tariffs imposed under emergency powers, sparking a broad relief rally. Despite initial concerns over weaker-than-expected Q4 GDP growth and mixed economic data, and lingering geopolitical tensions between the US and Iran, investor sentiment shifted positively, with technology and energy sectors leading the charge.

items.headline: S&P 500
items.statContext: Increased 0.7% on Friday. For the week, the S&P 500 advanced roughly 1%.

items.headline: NASDAQ Composite
items.statContext: Gained 0.9% on Friday. The Nasdaq Composite climbed more than 1% for the week.

items.headline: Dow Jones Industrial Average
items.statContext: Added 0.5% on Friday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average recorded a smaller but still positive increase for the week (0.3%).

items.headline: Amazon
items.summary: E-commerce companies rallied following the Supreme Court's tariff reversal.

items.headline: Walmart
items.summary: Walmart's strong quarterly results were overshadowed by disappointing guidance, contributing to its decline.

items.headline: Technology and Energy Lead Rally, Defensive Sectors Lag
items.summary: On Friday, the Technology and Energy sectors spearheaded the market rally, with the Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE) rising 1.9% and the Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) gaining 1%. This occurred as investors looked beyond AI to 'real economy' stocks, though AI-linked companies regained traction late in the week. Conversely, defensive 'bond proxy' sectors such as Utilities (XLU, down 1.7%) and Real Estate (XLRE, down 1.3%) lagged, weighed down by a hawkish Federal Reserve stance.

items.headline: Mixed Economic Data: GDP Slows, Jobless Claims Fall
items.summary: The U.S. economy's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of 1.4% in the fourth quarter of 2025, a significant slowdown from 4.4% in the third quarter and below consensus estimates, partly due to a government shutdown. However, initial jobless claims for the week ended February 14 decreased by 23,000 to 206,000, outperforming expectations. The trade deficit for December widened to $70.3 billion.

items.headline: Federal Reserve Remains Hawkish Amid Inflation Concerns
items.summary: Minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's January meeting revealed that while most members supported holding interest rates steady at 3.5%-3.75%, several participants were open to considering future rate hikes if inflation remains above the 2% target. The Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) price index increased 2.9% in Q4 2025, and December PCE prices rose 0.4% month-over-month, slightly above consensus.

items.headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Tariffs, New Duties Imposed
items.summary: The Supreme Court delivered a significant ruling today, striking down President Trump's sweeping tariffs previously enacted under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), which led to a market relief rally. Following the decision, President Trump announced the imposition of new temporary 10% global tariffs under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974.

items.headline: Earnings Season Continues: PPL Reports, NVIDIA Anticipated
items.summary: PPL Corporation ($PPL) reported its 2025 earnings results and provided a 2026 earnings forecast, projecting 7.2% growth over 2025 ongoing earnings. While Walmart ($WMT) had better-than-expected quarterly results, its guidance was disappointing. Looking ahead, investors are keenly awaiting fourth-quarter earnings reports next week from major technology companies, including NVIDIA ($NVDA), which is seen as a bellwether for global AI demand.
